content:
Whenever we perf-test a pr, the pr is marked as rollup=never even if rustbot says there were no interesting perf changes.
Would it make sense to not apply rollup=never in this case?

I think for the past 2 weeks the queue never managed to even fully catch up with all the rollup=never prs, so basically you can only have a pr merged if its
1) rolled up or
2) rollup=never (we didn't even touch the "rollup=iffy" at part of the queue yet so basically rollup=iff == merge=never, unless the iffy pr is added to a rollup which I'm hesitant to do because I don't want to it to somehow fail the rollup ci if I can avoid it)
Just yesterday we went from like 2-3 approved rollup=never prs to ~10 at the top of the queue, and just that would take maybe around 2 days/30-40 hours of ci-time to merge.
How many of those ~10 rollup=never PRs had no interesting perf changes? Seems like a reasonable change to me if this number is non-zero...

"no interesting" and actually no changes are often distinct; we don't always say there are changes even if they're present. I would be wary of introducing more noise into rollups. That said, it should be plausible to rollup only perf benched PRs, which should generally be pretty safe, particularly if we don't do too many at once (e.g., limit of 3).
